While cultural industry was impressing its standardized stamp on cur

melting pot® Speaking generally of all such ethnic groups* it seems safe to
say that previous to this melting pot experience* they had satisfied their
human needs for consumers’ goods and services in ways (even within a given ethnic
group) which were characterized by heterogeneity rather than homogeneity of
form and content® Flexibility and personalization rather than standardization
and impersonalization prevailed in adapting the means to the ends sought by the
customer® Thus the production of food-stuffs* clothing* household equipment
and utensils was at least partly commercial* but where the productive mode was
commercial it was characterized by custom-manufacturing rather than mass pro¬
duction® And the provision of entertainment* games* medical advice* moral
